questions.title: Two Numbers That Add Up (Explain Only)
questions.prompt: Explain how you would find two numbers in a small list that add up to a target, without writing code.
followups: Would you check all pairs or remember past numbers?
Give a small example using stock prices or financial data.
What edge case would you test first?

questions.title: Reverse a String (Steps)
questions.prompt: Explain step by step how you would reverse a string like "bloomberg".
followups: Where do you start?
How do you know when to stop?
How do you verify the result without printing it?

questions.title: Palindrome Check
questions.prompt: Explain how you would check if a word reads the same forward and backward.
followups: Would case or punctuation matter in a terminal search?
Why compare from both ends rather than reversing?
Give a simple example using a ticker symbol like 'AAPL'.

questions.title: Find the Largest Number
questions.prompt: Explain how you would find the largest number in a list of stock prices.
followups: How do you track the current maximum?
What if the list is empty or has negative prices?
Why is this approach simple and fast for real-time data?

questions.title: Counting Items (Stock Trades)
questions.prompt: Explain how you would count how many times each stock ticker appears in a list of trades.
followups: What is the key and value in your data structure?
Why is this better than counting manually?
Where is this useful at Bloomberg (e.g., trade volume)?

questions.title: Remove Duplicates (Ticker Symbols)
questions.prompt: Explain how you would remove duplicate ticker symbols from a list.
followups: How do you detect duplicates?
Does the order of the first occurrence matter?
What edge case would you test (e.g., all duplicates)?

questions.title: Binary Search (Idea Only)
questions.prompt: Explain how you could search a sorted list of bond yields faster than checking every item.
followups: Why must the list be sorted?
What does "cutting in half" mean?
Give a real-life example at Bloomberg (e.g., finding a price).

questions.title: Merge Two Sorted Lists
questions.prompt: Explain how you would merge two sorted lists of trade timestamps into one sorted list.
followups: What do you compare first?
What happens when one list ends?
How would you handle millisecond precision?

questions.title: Valid Parentheses (Idea Level)
questions.prompt: Explain how you would check if brackets in a Bloomberg Terminal query are correctly matched.
followups: Why does order matter?
What makes a query string invalid?
Give an example of a complex nested query.

questions.title: Loops (Practical Use)
questions.prompt: Explain when and why you would use a loop to process incoming market data.
followups: What happens if a loop never stops (infinite loop in production)?
Why are loops useful for streaming data?
Give a simple use case (e.g., calculating average price).

questions.title: If Statements
questions.prompt: Explain how an if statement helps a trading algorithm make decisions.
followups: What happens if the condition is false?
Give a real-life example (e.g., if price > threshold, execute trade).
Why are conditions important in low-latency systems?

questions.title: Functions (Purpose)
questions.prompt: Explain why breaking a financial data parser into functions is helpful.
followups: How do functions reduce repetition?
How do they help with unit testing?
What happens without functions in a large codebase?

questions.title: Variables (Usage)
questions.prompt: Explain how variables help store and manage real-time stock prices.
followups: Why not hardcode values?
What happens when variables change during market hours?
How do you name variables for clarity in a trading system?

questions.title: Arrays vs Linked Lists
questions.prompt: Explain one practical difference between arrays and linked lists for storing order books.
followups: Which is easier for random access?
Which is more flexible for inserts/deletes?
Why might Bloomberg choose one for a specific feature?

questions.title: Big-O (Plain English)
questions.prompt: Explain what Big-O helps developers think about when processing millions of trades per second.
followups: Why does performance matter in financial systems?
Is faster always better? (Consider power/heat).
When is a simple O(n²) solution good enough for prototyping?

questions.title: Debugging Basics
questions.prompt: Your Bloomberg Terminal feature is not updating prices. Explain the first steps you would take to debug it.
followups: Why start with the network connection?
What tools help (logs, breakpoints)?
When do you ask a senior engineer for help?

questions.title: Testing Basics
questions.prompt: Explain how you would test a function that calculates the moving average of a stock price.
followups: Why test multiple inputs (zero volume, negative prices)?
What happens if you skip testing?
How do automated tests save time in a CI/CD pipeline?

questions.title: APIs (Usage)
questions.prompt: Explain how a Bloomberg Terminal feature might use an API to get historical data.
followups: Why not store all historical data locally on the terminal?
What data format would you expect (JSON, protobuf)?
Give an example of a REST endpoint for 'AAPL' prices.

questions.title: REST Basics
questions.prompt: Explain what a REST API is using a simple example like retrieving a company's profile.
followups: What does GET do?
What does POST do for submitting a trade?
Why is REST popular for internal Bloomberg services?

questions.title: Frontend vs Backend
questions.prompt: Explain how the Bloomberg Terminal frontend and backend work together to display a chart.
followups: Which part handles user input (e.g., typing a ticker)?
Which part calculates the chart data?
How do they communicate (WebSockets vs HTTP)?

questions.title: Bloomberg Value: Impact
questions.prompt: Tell me about a time you built something that had a measurable impact on users.
followups: How did you measure that impact?
What was your specific role?
How did you know the users were satisfied?

questions.title: Bloomberg Value: Ownership
questions.prompt: Tell me about a time you took ownership of a task outside your defined responsibilities.
followups: What motivated you to step up?
What challenges did you face?
What did you learn about yourself?

questions.title: Bloomberg Value: Collaboration
questions.prompt: Describe a time you worked closely with someone to solve a difficult problem.
followups: How did you divide the work?
What happened when you disagreed?
What was the outcome?

questions.title: Bloomberg Value: Resilience
questions.prompt: Tell me about a time a project did not go as planned. How did you handle it?
followups: What went wrong?
How did you communicate the delay?
What did you do differently next time?

questions.title: Why Bloomberg? (Intern Focus)
questions.prompt: Why do you want to intern at Bloomberg specifically?
followups: What Bloomberg product do you use or admire?
What do you know about Bloomberg's engineering culture?
How does this internship fit your career goals?

questions.title: Implement a Simple Linked List
questions.prompt: Explain how you would implement your own linked list class in C++ or Java.
followups: How do you achieve O(1) access to the head?
How would you allocate new memory and resize dynamically?
What strategy would you use to decide how much extra memory to allocate?

questions.title: Telephone Directory Lookup
questions.prompt: What data structure would you use for a telephone lookup that is efficient both ways (search by name and search by number)?
followups: Why not just use a single hash map?
How would you keep both maps in sync?
What is the memory trade-off?

questions.title: Maximum Nesting Depth
questions.prompt: Explain how you would find the maximum nesting depth of parentheses in a string.
followups: How do you track the current depth?
How would you return the indices of the deepest pairs?
What if there are multiple maximum depth pairs?

questions.title: Stock Trade Tracker (Basic)
questions.prompt: Explain how you would efficiently store and update the total quantity of trades for a stock ticker (e.g., 'AAPL' and 'MSFT').
followups: What data structure gives O(1) update and retrieval?
How would you handle a burst of 10,000 trades per second?
What if you later need the top K most traded stocks?

questions.title: String Permutation Palindrome
questions.prompt: Explain how you would determine if the permutation of a string can form a palindrome.
followups: What character counts matter?
How do you handle an even vs odd length string?
Give an example using 'bloomberg' or 'ticker'.

questions.title: Find the 2 Innermost Characters
questions.prompt: Explain how you would find the two innermost characters within a string.
followups: What does 'innermost' mean for nested structures?
How do you handle strings without nesting?
Walk through an example like 'a(b(c)d)e'.

questions.title: Balanced Binary Tree Check
questions.prompt: Explain how you would check if a binary tree is balanced (height difference of subtrees <= 1).
followups: What is the base case?
Why is it important to avoid recomputing heights?
What is the time complexity of your approach?

questions.title: Linked List Cycle (Conceptual)
questions.prompt: Explain how you would detect if a linked list has a cycle.
followups: Why does Floyd's algorithm (tortoise and hare) work?
What is the space complexity?
What if you cannot modify the list?

questions.title: Swap Opposite Nodes
questions.prompt: Explain the idea behind swapping the opposite nodes of a binary tree.
followups: What does 'opposite' mean in this context (mirror/invert)?
How would you traverse the tree?
Can you do this iteratively with a queue?

questions.title: Validate IP Address
questions.prompt: Explain how you would validate whether a given string is a valid IPv4 address.
followups: What are the four main conditions?
How do you handle leading zeros?
What about IPv6? How would you extend it?

questions.title: Time Complexity of Functions
questions.prompt: Explain what time complexity means and give an example of O(1), O(n), and O(n²) operations.
followups: What is the complexity of array access vs linked list search?
Why is this important for Bloomberg's real-time systems?
How do you measure performance empirically?

questions.title: Fibonacci Sequence (Optimization)
questions.prompt: Explain how you would compute the nth Fibonacci number. What are the trade-offs of recursion vs iteration?
followups: Why is naive recursion exponential?
How does memoization help?
What is the space complexity of the iterative approach?

questions.title: First Non-Repeating Character
questions.prompt: Explain how you would find the first character in a string that does not repeat.
followups: What data structure tracks character counts?
How many passes over the string do you need?
What if the string is very long (e.g., a financial feed)?

questions.title: String Concatenation (Performance)
questions.prompt: Explain why concatenating many strings in a loop is inefficient and how to do it better.
followups: Why are strings immutable in languages like Java and C#?
How does StringBuilder or StringBuffer work?
When would you notice the performance difference at Bloomberg?

questions.title: Basic Error Handling
questions.prompt: Explain what you would do if your program encounters a null pointer exception when processing a trade.
followups: Why is it important to handle errors gracefully in a terminal?
What information should the error log contain?
How does error handling improve user trust?

questions.title: Comments in Code
questions.prompt: Explain why adding comments to code is important in a large codebase like Bloomberg's.
followups: When should you add comments?
What makes a good comment vs obvious code?
Can comments ever be misleading or harmful?

questions.title: Version Control Basics
questions.prompt: Explain why using version control (like Git) is critical for a team of 20 engineers working on the Terminal.
followups: How does it help with concurrent development?
What happens if you make a mistake and commit breaking code?
Why does Bloomberg use version control for compliance?

questions.title: Caching Concept
questions.prompt: Explain why caching frequently accessed financial data (like a stock price) can improve performance.
followups: What Bloomberg data might be cached?
What are the risks of serving stale cached data?
How do you invalidate the cache when a price updates?

questions.title: Mobile vs Desktop Experience
questions.prompt: Explain why Bloomberg might need a different experience for mobile vs the desktop Terminal.
followups: What differences exist in screen size and input?
Why is mobile important for traders on the go?
How would you prioritize features for a mobile MVP?

questions.title: Accessibility Basics
questions.prompt: Explain why making the Bloomberg Terminal accessible to users with disabilities is important.
followups: Who benefits from accessible design beyond the target audience?
What simple improvements help with screen readers?
Why does Bloomberg care about accessibility?

questions.title: Security Basics
questions.prompt: Explain why security is crucial for Bloomberg's financial data systems.
followups: What sensitive data does Bloomberg handle?
What are basic security practices for API authentication?
How does security build trust with financial institutions?

questions.title: Scaling Concepts
questions.prompt: Explain why Bloomberg needs to handle massive spikes in traffic during market open.
followups: What challenges come with sudden increases in users?
How might Bloomberg prepare for these predictable peaks?
Why is scaling important for business reputation?

questions.title: Team Collaboration
questions.prompt: Explain why working well in a team is important at Bloomberg.
followups: What makes a good team member?
How do teams solve complex problems like a new Terminal feature?
Why does Bloomberg value collaboration over individual heroics?

questions.title: Learning from Mistakes
questions.prompt: Tell me about a time you made a mistake in code and what you learned from it.
followups: How did you discover the mistake?
What did you do to fix it?
How did this help you prevent similar issues?

questions.title: Technical Challenge (Easy)
questions.prompt: Describe a technical challenge you faced in a past project and how you approached it.
followups: What made it challenging?
What resources did you use to overcome it?
What was the outcome?

questions.title: Project Experience
questions.prompt: Tell me about a programming project you are proud of.
followups: What was your specific role?
What did you learn technically?
What would you improve if you had more time?

questions.title: User-Focused Thinking
questions.prompt: How would you improve the Bloomberg Terminal for a specific type of user (e.g., a bond trader)?
followups: What pain points have you observed or can imagine?
How would you implement your idea simply?
How would you measure if the improvement was successful?

questions.title: Adaptability
questions.prompt: Tell me about a time you had to learn a new programming language or framework quickly.
followups: What was the situation?
How did you approach learning (docs, courses, pair programming)?
What was the result of your effort?

questions.title: Communication Skills
questions.prompt: Explain a technical concept (like a hash table) to someone without a technical background (e.g., a salesperson).
followups: How do you simplify complex ideas?
Why is clear communication important at Bloomberg?
How do you know if someone understands your explanation?

questions.title: Initiative
questions.prompt: Tell me about a time you went beyond what was required in a project or job.
followups: What motivated you to do more?
What was the impact of your extra effort?
What did you learn from taking initiative?

questions.title: Time Management
questions.prompt: How do you prioritize tasks when you have multiple deadlines (e.g., exams, projects, internship work)?
followups: What strategies do you use (e.g., Eisenhower matrix, to-do lists)?
How do you handle unexpected urgent tasks?
What tools help you stay organized?

questions.title: Feedback Reception
questions.prompt: Tell me about a time you received constructive feedback on your code or design.
followups: What was the feedback?
How did you initially react?
What did you change, and how did it improve your work?

questions.title: Problem Solving Approach
questions.prompt: Walk me through how you would approach a new programming problem from scratch.
followups: Where do you start (requirements, examples)?
How do you break down complex problems?
At what point do you ask for help or clarification?

questions.title: Bloomberg Innovation
questions.prompt: What Bloomberg innovation or technology impresses you most?
followups: Why does it impress you?
How does it help financial professionals?
What technical challenges might it involve (e.g., low latency, data volume)?

questions.title: Career Goals
questions.prompt: What do you hope to gain from an internship at Bloomberg?
followups: What specific skills do you want to develop?
How does this internship fit your long-term career goals?
What unique opportunities does Bloomberg offer that other companies don't?

questions.title: Diversity and Inclusion
questions.prompt: Why is diversity important in technology teams?
followups: How does diversity improve product development?
What can individual engineers do to promote inclusion?
Why does Bloomberg value diverse perspectives?
